instruction: What are the steps to using random (yet coherent) text as filler content within your Word document?
output:
Sure, there are many reasons why you might want to add random filler text to a Word document. For example, when you're writing a newspaper article and you don't quite have enough content yet, or maybe you're just experimenting with design options and need some filler text to see how the page will look with different fonts and sizes. Whatever your reason for wanting to add random text to your Word document, it's easy to do so using a built-in feature that Word has to offer.
1. Open up a new Word document.: You can do this by clicking on "New" in the "Files" tab of the upper left corner of Word. From there, select "Microsoft Word Template," and then click on "Blank Document."
2. Type your main body text.: Add your introduction, body, and conclusion as you normally would. After you've typed all of your content, type a period at the end of your last sentence, and then hit "Enter" once more to start a new line.
3. Go to "Insert.": This is located in the "File" tab in the upper left corner of Word.
4. Select "Text Box.": This option is in the "Insert" menu, under "Shapes."
5. Click on "OK": You should now see a box with rounded corners that says "Place Text Here."
6. Type your random text.: Make sure that the font is one that you want to use on your final document, and make sure that it fits well within the text box.
If you'd like to change the font size or style, right click inside the text box and select "Format Font" from the context menu that appears. You can also use the "Font" option in the "Home" tab to change the font after you've started typing.

instruction: Make a list of desirable Skills for software engineers to add to LinkedIn.
output:
A software engineer is a person who applies the principles of software engineering to the design, development, maintenance, testing, and evaluation of computer software. They are responsible for the development and maintenance of software systems, writing code, and debugging programs. Software engineers also have knowledge of algorithms and data structures, and they can apply these to solve complex problems.
To be an effective software engineer, you should possess strong problem-solving skills, good communication skills, and the ability to work well in a team environment. You should also have a strong understanding of computer science concepts, such as object-oriented programming and algorithm design. Additionally, knowledge of scripting languages, such as Python or Java, is important for building software applications.

Mathematics Homework LaTeX Template

Scientific Paper LaTeX Template

instruction:
Write a simple guide for uploading the bibliography database
 on Overleaf.
output:
Overleaf is a great online editor for LaTeX documents. In this short guide, we'll show you how to upload your bibliography database on Overleaf so that you can easily add citations and bibliographies to your documents.
1. Go to https://www.overleaf.com/start in your web browser.
2. Click Sign Up in the top-right corner of the page.
3. Enter your personal information and create a password.
4. After creating your account, click Get Started on the left menu.
5. Choose a template from the list of available templates.
6. Select "Upload bibliography database" from the right-hand menu.
7. Browse your computer for the Zotero database file.
8. After selecting the file, click Upload.
9. Wait for the file to upload. Once it has finished uploading, you will see the database listed under "My libraries".
10. Click on the library name to open it.
11. Click on the green plus button to start adding items to your bibliography.
12. Search for the item you want to cite in the search bar at the top of the page.
13. Select the item you want to cite and click Add Selected to your bibliography.
14. Repeat steps 12-13 for each item you want to cite.
15. Click on the green checkmark to generate your bibliography.
16. Click Preview to see what your bibliography looks like.
17. Click Download PDF to download a copy of your document with the generated bibliography.
And that's it! With your bibliography uploaded to Overleaf, you can easily add citations and bibliographies to your documents with just a few clicks.

instruction: You should take the time to read the situation and problem carefully and give the best advice you can.
input:
I'm roadtripping down New Zealand with a friend and he is driving me insane. He hasn't enjoyed all the tours we've been on and doesn't want to chat about ANYTHING. We're a week into our trip and this is the quietest I've ever been when hanging out with another person as he rebuffs all my attempts at conversation. He wears his airpods in the car and around the accommodation - not that I've kept trying to talk to him. Honestly, he is bringing some seriously bad vibes to everything and it's ruining my trip.
We don't have anything booked in yet for the South Island, so I'm planning to ditch him in Wellington at the ferry. Probably book my own car in Picton and just relax alone for the rest of the trip. (Just thinking about it is such sharp relief that it makes me feel emotional. I'll pay whatever price I have to just to get away from him.)
Obviously telling him he is ruining my trip with his negative energy isn't the best way to approach this.
Any advice for the best approach so we can split amicably? Or at least not have an argument that ends with very hurt feelings?
output:
Also, I would like to suggest he find his own car in Picton but don't know how I could bring that up without sounding unreasonable. Should I just pay for the whole car and let him deal with finding one when we get there? (We're both under 25 so it's not as expensive as I imagine it would be for an older couple.)
EDIT: I have considered telling him I need some time away from him on my own. I think that will probably make him angry and defensive. Or perhaps I should say I want to go to a few of the same places alone and see if he can handle that.
new-zealand roadtrip
Have you tried talking to him about his negative attitude? Something like "Hey, I notice you're not having a good time, is everything ok?"
No, because he's not saying anything at all. And I don't want to lead into a conversation where he'll deny everything and then start accusing me of being manipulative or overreacting. – user14071 May 28 '19 at 13:46
I would start by apologizing for not making the trip better for him so far. Try to understand that he might be feeling lonely and out of his comfort zone, even though it’s your trip. Start talking about what he’d like to do and try to find activities that please both of you. You could also split up some of the time, but do so in a way that makes sense logistically and doesn’t put you in separate cars.
As for the car, offer to pay for your half up front, and then he pays the other half once he finds his own car. If you want things to change, you’ll need to show willingness to accommodate his needs as well, even if they aren’t what

The bands feature a heart outline with the colors of the rainbow – red, orange, yellow, green, blue and purple – that represent diversity and inclusion.
The teams will also wear special-edition shirts featuring the one-love logo. The shirts are available for purchase, with proceeds going to support organizations that promote inclusion and equality.
The teams hope that by wearing the bands and shirts, they will send a strong message of support for inclusion and equality. They believe that by standing together, they can make a difference and help create a more inclusive and equal society.
The OneLove campaign is a great example of how sport can be used as a platform to promote important social issues. By wearing the bands and shirts, the teams are showing their support for inclusion and equality and sending a powerful message to everyone watching. It is inspiring to see such a united effort from so many teams and countries to promote a positive and inclusive message.

instruction: Discuss the origins and history of the word that has been given to you.
input: oblique
output:
stroke (plural oblique strokes)
(typography) A character with an oblique stroke is one whose horizontal and vertical strokes are not perpendicular to each other.
A cursive letter has oblique strokes.
1879, James T. Shotwell, The Penman's Guide to Ornamental Lettering: :In the formation of the letters of the Roman alphabet, there is also a very wide range of variation, depending upon whether the strokes are made diagonally or horizontally, oblique or straight. ,
1967 April 9, “The New Photogravure”, in The Times (London, England), Sunday edition, page 15:
The forms that he evolved for his typefaces were variations on traditional roman types, using many diagonal elements (oblique strokes) and contrasting thick and thin lines.

The city is also a hub for technology, science, and space exploration, with the European Space Agency having its headquarters there.

instruction: You will need to guide this person through the scenario they have described for the interview.
input:
Finally! After a while of shooting in the dark and frantically fiddling with sample inputs on the whiteboard, you've came up with an algorithm for solving the coding question your interviewer gave you.
Whew. Such a relief to have a clear path forward. To not be flailing anymore.
Now you're cruising, getting ready to code up your solution.
When suddenly, your interviewer throws you a curve ball.
"What if we thought of the problem this way?"
You feel a tension we've all felt during the coding interview:
"Try to listen to what they're saying...but don't lose your train of thought...ugh, I can't do both!"
output:
Interviewers aren't trying to throw you off. They want to help you succeed. They want to see how you think on your feet, how well you can explain your thought process, and how you can adapt to a new perspective. But they could be making it harder on you by springing curve balls.
So here's what to do when an interviewer throws you a curve ball.
Step 1: Listen and clarify
Hear them out. Keep your body language relaxed and open, show that you are listening. Nod and smile, but don't let those expressions distract from your eyes which should be focused on their face.
Don't be afraid to ask clarifying questions. "Could you please explain what you mean by that?" is a totally acceptable response, especially if you feel like you've lost the thread of what they're saying.
Step 2: Evaluate potential impact
As your interviewer talks, evaluate the potential impact of their suggestion. Is it significant? Could it change the way you approach the problem?
Step 3: Adapt your plan
If their idea will have a big impact, let them know you're hearing them out. "That's a fascinating idea. I hadn't considered it before. Let me see if this adaptation makes sense."
If their idea won't change much, acknowledge it quickly then switch back to your original train of thought. "Yeah, that's true. But I think this is still the best approach."
Step 4: Thank them
Thank your interviewer for their input. "I really appreciate your insight there. It's helped me refine my thinking on the problem."
It helps to thank them even if their idea didn't make a big difference. Interviewers put a lot of work into preparing for coding interviews, and

instruction: You are given a programming problem and its implementation. Analyze the problem and implementation and explain the algorithm and approach used to solve the problem.
input:
Table: Person
| Column Name | Type     |
| personId          | int         |
| lastName         | varchar |
| firstName         | varchar |
personId is the primary key column for this table.
This table contains information about the ID of some persons and their first and last names.
Table: Address
| Column Name | Type     |
| addressId        | int         |
| personId          | int         |
| city                   | varchar|
| state                | varchar |
addressId is the primary key column for this table.
Each row of this table contains information about the city and state of one person with ID = PersonId.
Write an SQL query to report the first name, last name, city, and state of each person in the Person table. If the address of a personId is not present in the Address table, report null instead.
Return the result table in any order.
Implementation:
select FirstName, LastName, City, State
from Person left join Address
on Person.PersonId = Address.PersonId
;
output: This query uses a Cartesian product to produce the output table. In other words, it selects all possible combinations of rows from the Person and Address tables. The ON clause is used to match the PersonId columns in each table. The result set is then filtered to include only the columns being reported.

instruction: An evaluation of the article's quality should be carried out. In order to do so, you should review the quality of the writing and the explanation of the topic.
input:
The 20th century saw a revolution in music listening as the radio gained popularity worldwide and new media and technologies were developed to record, edit and distribute music. Music performances became increasingly visual with the broadcast and recording of performances.
20th-century music brought new freedom and wide experimentation with new musical styles and forms that challenged the accepted rules of music of earlier periods. The invention of musical amplification and electronic instruments, especially the synthesizer, in the mid-20th century revolutionized classical and popular music, and accelerated the development of new forms of music.
output:
The late 19th and early 20th centuries saw a dramatic increase in the popularity of consumer electronics, such as the radio. The radio allowed for increased access to music as it could be broadcast to large numbers of people at once. This led to the development of new styles of music that were tailored for mass appeal. Examples of these types of music include Tin Pan Alley and Hillbilly music.
New media and technologies also emerged during this time that allowed for easier recording, editing, and distribution of music. The phonograph was patented in 1877 and began to be mass-produced by the beginning of the 20th century. It revolutionized the music industry by making it possible to distribute recordings of musical performances on a large scale. In the 1920s, the talking picture or "talkie" replaced silent films and introduced sound recording to cinema. During this period, musicians began to be paid royalties for their work, which had previously been considered an honorarium.
The performance of music became more visual with the advent of television and video recordings. The introduction of rock and roll culture in the 1950s made performing on stage even more important. Some performers such as Elvis Presley and The Beatles became extremely popular, selling out concerts wherever they played.
Music of the 20th century is often characterized by its diversity and experimentation. New styles of music called modern music were created, including atonal music, twelve-tone music, and serialism. Important composers of the 20th century included Arnold Schoenberg, Igor Stravinsky, John Cage, and Karlheinz Stockhausen. Jazz music developed from ragtime and blues to encompass a variety of styles generally characterized by the improvisation of soloists

instruction: Provide a detailed explanation of the steps that are required in order to construct the given project.
input: Steam Engine Using an Empty Beer Can
output:
1. Gather the materials
2. Cut a rectangular hole in the center of the can, using the jaw plier. The hole should be about 2 inches long and 1/4 inch wide.
3. Drill two holes on opposite sides of the can, near the bottom. The holes will hold the steam engines valves.
4. Bend the wire into the shape of an 'H' with the pointy end cutting into the side of the can. Attach one end of the wire to one of the valves and the other end to a penny or washer. The penny or washer will act as a weight and help the valve open and close.
5. Fill the can with water up to the top edge of the hole you cut earlier. Add 1 tablespoon of vinegar, which will create carbon dioxide gas when heated, making the water boil faster.
6. Place a potato over one of the holes of the valve. This will act as a piston, pushing the water around the engine.
7. Light a match and hold it near the opening of the can. When the can is hot, remove the match and quickly put it underneath the potato. The expansion of the gases created by the match will force the potato to move, thereby operating the steam engine.

instruction: Describe how to prepare the given food in your own words. Note down the ingredients you will need and the steps you will take to prepare them.
input: Chewy Chocolate Chip Cookies
output:
Recipe
Ingredients:
- 2 cups all-purpose flour
- 1 teaspoon baking soda
- ½ teaspoon salt
- ¾ cup unsalted butter, softened
- ¾ cup granulated sugar
- ¾ cup brown sugar
- 2 large eggs
- 2 teaspoons vanilla extract
- 2 cups semi-sweet chocolate chips
Instructions:
1. Preheat the oven to 375°F (190°C).
2. In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, baking soda, and salt.
3. In a larger bowl, beat the butter and sugars together until creamy. Add the eggs one at a time, beating well after each addition. Stir in the vanilla.
4. Gradually mix in the dry ingredients until just combined. Fold in the chocolate chips.
5. Drop spoonfuls of dough onto a baking sheet lined with parchment paper.
6. Bake for 9-11 minutes, or until golden brown around the edges. Cool on the baking sheet for 5 minutes before transferring to a wire rack to cool completely.
7. Enjoy warm or store in an airtight container at room temperature up to 3 days.

instruction: Suggest a recipe for a vegan dessert.
output:
Creamy Vegan Chocolate Pudding
Ingredients:
1 cup unsweetened almond milk
2 tablespoons vegan chocolate powder (cacao powder)
1 teaspoon maple syrup
1/4 teaspoon vanilla extract
1 tablespoon ground flaxseed
2 tablespoons coconut cream
Optional toppings: shredded coconut, sliced almonds, fresh berries
Instructions:
1. In a blender, combine the almond milk, cacao powder, maple syrup, and vanilla extract. Blend until smooth.
2. In a separate bowl, whisk together the flaxseed and coconut cream until well combined.
3. Add the flaxseed mixture to the blender and blend until smooth.
4. Pour the pudding into individual serving dishes or a large bowl.
5. Top with desired toppings.
6. Refrigerate for at least 30 minutes before serving.
7. Enjoy!

instruction: Verify the correctness of the given statement.
input: "For all integers j and k, if j and k are odd, then jk is odd."
output: let j, k be integers, where j and k are odd. then by definition of odd, there exist integers a and b such that 0 < a < j and 0 < b < k. then by the distributive property, we have (a*j)*k = a*j*k = a*jk. since a*j and a*k are both odd, so is a*jk.

instruction: Provide a formula for computing the nth term in the given sequence
output:
The formula for the nth term in this sequence is:
a_n = 5 + (n-1)d
where d = 9
So, the general term for this sequence is:
a_n = 5 + (n-1)9
Simplifying this expression, we get:
a_n = 5n - 14
Therefore, the nth term in this sequence is:
a_n = 5n - 14

instruction: Create a short, concise summary of the paper based on its abstract.
input: Few-shot learning (FSL) is one of the key future steps in machine learning and raises a lot of attention. In this paper, we focus on the FSL problem of dialogue understanding, which contains two closely related tasks: intent detection and slot filling. Dialogue understanding has been proven to benefit a lot from jointly learning the two sub-tasks. However, such joint learning becomes challenging in the few-shot scenarios: on the one hand, the sparsity of samples greatly magnifies the difficulty of modeling the connection between the two tasks; on the other hand, how to jointly learn multiple tasks in the few-shot setting is still less investigated. In response to this, we introduce FewJoint, the first FSL benchmark for joint dialogue understanding. FewJoint provides a new corpus with 59 different dialogue domains from real industrial API and a code platform to ease FSL experiment set-up, which are expected to advance the research of this field. Further, we find that insufficient performance of the few-shot setting often leads to noisy sharing between two sub-task and disturbs joint learning. To tackle this, we guide slot with explicit intent information and propose a novel trust gating mechanism that blocks low-confidence intent information to ensure high quality sharing. Besides, we introduce a Reptile-based meta-learning strategy to achieve better generalization in unseen few-shot domains. In the experiments, the proposed method brings significant improvements on two datasets and achieve new state-of-the-art performance.
output: The code and data are available at https://github.com/fewjoint-team/fewjoint.

instruction: For a quick and efficient office workout, suggest a short routine.
output:
As an AI language model, I don't have personal preferences, but here are some suggestions for a quick and efficient office workout:
1. Jumping jacks - Start by standing up straight with your feet hip-width apart. Jump up and touch your hands together above your head, then land in the same position and repeat. Continue jumping jacking for about a minute.
2. Squats - Stand with your feet hip-width apart and place your hands on your hips. Slowly bend down and sit back into a squat, making sure to keep your back straight. Hold for a few seconds, then push back up to the starting position. Repeat for about a minute.
3. Planks - Get down on the ground and prop yourself up on your elbows and toes. Keep your body in a straight line and hold for about a minute.
4. Calf raises - Stand up straight and stretch out your arms. Bend your knees and lower yourself into a lunge position. Then push back up and straighten your legs while doing calf raises. Continue for about a minute.
5. Wall push-ups - Stand facing a wall and place your hands on it at shoulder height. Bend your elbows and lower your chest towards the wall, pushing back up and repeating. Continue for about a minute.

The manifesto was originally created in 2001 by a group of software developers who were disillusioned with traditional project management approaches and wanted to create a better way of developing software. The Agile Manifesto has since become one of the most widely used and respected frameworks for Agile software development.

instruction: Design a simple training challenge on Strava that everyone could attend.
output:
Dan Pink, author of Drive: The Surprising Truth About What Motivates Us, describes three key factors for motivating people in his TED talk. In summary, they are:
Autonomy – the desire to direct our own lives
Mastery – the urge to get better and better at things
Purpose – the yearning to do what we do in the service of something larger than ourselves
I’d like to suggest a simple training challenge that addresses all three of these factors on Strava. My idea is to create an event called “The 50/12 Challenge”, where participants would attempt to ride 50 miles or run 12 miles in under two hours on a specific day. Here are some reasons why I think this is a good idea:
1. Autonomy – participants can choose when they want to complete the challenge, as long as it’s within a month. They can also choose whether to do it on a road bike or a mountain bike, or on foot.
2. Mastery – the challenge requires a reasonable level of fitness, but it’s not so difficult that it’s impossible for most people. By setting a time limit, participants have the opportunity to improve their performance over time as their fitness increases.
3. Purpose – the challenge has a clear goal, which serves as a motivator. Participants know that they need to complete the challenge within two hours to earn the “badge” on Strava. Additionally, completing the challenge contributes to a greater cause, such as supporting a local charity.
Overall, the 50/12 Challenge would be a fun and engaging way to motivate people to train while also addressing key elements of motivation as described by Dan Pink.
